A #digitaleuro would combine the efficiency of a digital payment instrument with the safety of central bank money, which, together with cash, would offer greater choice and access to simple ways of paying https://t.co/RiwOCers68

Our public consultation on a #digitaleuro is open until 12 January. Give us your views on the benefits and challenges of issuing a digital euro and on its possible design https://t.co/cbioWMqpSc https://t.co/oTDNRLexrD

Would you like to know more about what the ECB does? Organise a presentation by an ECB expert for a group and learn more about ECB-related topics. The ECB Visitor Centre is offering virtual lectures – get in touch to schedule yours! https://t.co/2L2fuo9Vp7 https://t.co/KQWKsjUf8U

Share your input! The working group on euro risk-free rates is seeking feedback on fallbacks for the Euribor rate via two public consultations. Send us your views before 15 January 2021

Enria: Our activities going forward will be guided by the repercussions of the crisis in terms of credit risk, digitalisation and consolidation. Green finance will also be on our agenda, together with cyber risk, transparency and simpler processes https://t.co/tcAAQJ7Rtt 2/2

(THREAD) The key focus of our work now is the measurement of credit risk and the risks to banks’ balance sheets arising from the coronavirus crisis, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria tells @boersenzeitung. We are also working to improve bank profitability and governance 1/2 https://t.co/f9o61KJvrL

The ECB provides stability and helps building a bridge towards economic recovery, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. More about the economic outlook for 2021, and the role of the coronavirus vaccine on #TheECBPodcast with host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/YclAdu82Kk https://t.co/GetOj2HZ36

Chief Economist Philip R. Lane explains how monetary policy can contribute to the economic recovery and when fiscal policy needs to take the lead. Want to hear more? Tune into the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with our host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/YclAdu82Kk https://t.co/4iD8SmE0UR
Working Paper: Losers amongst the losers: the welfare effects of the Great Recession across cohorts https://t.co/mYcZ8UPxRa

A loan that looks unlikely to be repaid in full becomes non-performing and will probably generate a loss. Banks prepare for expected losses by booking provisions. Read our Explainer to find out what it means and what coverage for non-performing loans is https://t.co/2qpmvDdUYb https://t.co/mbOX3KkbbW

How will the coronavirus vaccine affect economic recovery? Where do we stand after nine months of fighting the crisis? What’s the role of the ECB’s monetary policy? Tune into the #TheECBPodcast with Chief Economist Philip R. Lane and host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/YclAdupDBS https://t.co/lXrO9WVjeh

European banking supervision could not have become reality without Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa’s combination of vision and realism, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria at an event paying tribute to Padoa-Schioppa, a key figure in European policymaking https://t.co/5klPNNo1IN https://t.co/q8Ec4w9Kgk

The ECB nominates Executive Board member @FrankElderson as Vice-Chair of the Supervisory Board. Full press release https://t.co/RT463P97Ts

Evolution, not revolution. This is how Vice-President Luis de Guindos described the aim of the #ECBstrategyreview for our monetary policy during the #ECBYouthDialogue with students from @UniCologne (@ECON_tribute, @Iwp_Uni_Koeln). Find out more https://t.co/fF6yBo7OCJ https://t.co/hHhxYc2ppe

Avoid zombies and help sleeping beauties: this was Vice-President’s Luis de Guindos’s advice during the #ECBYouthDialogue with @UniCologne @ECON_tribute, @Iwp_Uni_Koeln to make sure that viable companies survive the #coronavirus crisis. Find out more https://t.co/b5Wl4stnvC https://t.co/oOLJ4X1h3U
⚡️ Missed our live Twitter Q&A with ECB Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel? Catch up here! #AskECB https://t.co/cUAhmYzD4K
https://t.co/YNLm9XU2rO
Time to wrap up. Thanks a lot for your questions – I really enjoyed the chat and look forward to doing it again soon. Take care! #AskECB https://t.co/j373jUC3Jd

Schnabel: We study the impact of our measures continuously and assess their proportionality, taking into account potential side effects. Our analyses have shown consistently that positive effects have exceeded negative ones. Otherwise, we would change our policies. #AskECB https://t.co/IELlYWr5ej

Schnabel: To take policy decisions and assess their impacts we use a large suite of different models and analyses provided by ECB and Eurosystem staff. These models are constantly adjusted to take into account the changing economic environment, new data and methods. #AskECB https://t.co/iajhd79aMC

Schnabel: The current pandemic is a good example of how the ECB has supported financial stability by preventing a financial crisis. Our policies have also helped to protect millions of jobs, which mainly benefits people with lower incomes. #AskECB https://t.co/QU3oAdTNYl

Schnabel: A digital euro is explored to ensure the access to public money in a digital world. Its potential introduction is not motivated by monetary policy reasons. Our public consultation has generated considerable interest https://t.co/fXFJFhaZWR. #AskECB https://t.co/vDKyVRCGrQ

Schnabel: The risks from climate change will be increasingly taken into account in the risk assessments of banks’ balance sheet. Please read the excellent speech by Andrea Enria on this topic. #AskECB https://t.co/JlVf8I8ome https://t.co/4oTtekCq4t

Schnabel: Economy literacy is something I care about very much - not just when teaching at university but also now at the ECB. By improving our communication, we hope to also contribute to advancing economic literacy. But schools should also play a greater role here. #AskECB https://t.co/TAgotXJQy4

Schnabel: The European Commission’s taxonomy is an important first step in assessing climate impact. A more complete taxonomy, including less green activities, would be a useful complement. #AskECB https://t.co/usCqSXbCo2

Schnabel: The sources of shocks are important for the pass-through of exchange rate changes to inflation. Our analysis shows that several factors have been behind the recent appreciation of the euro, including prospects of a faster global recovery. #AskECB https://t.co/oJ92OSbOqi
Schnabel: Two😉 #AskECB https://t.co/NG8vK338Jl

Schnabel: We took swift actions to counter the shock from the pandemic on our inflation outlook. We remain undeterred in our commitment to bring inflation back to our medium-term aim of below but close to 2%. But the speed of return depends on the shocks we are facing. #AskECB https://t.co/MssfX18Azj

Schnabel: We are conducting extensive analyses, and central banks across the euro area are hosting listening events with the public and with experts. The Governing Council expects to conclude the review in the 2nd half of 2021 #AskECB More information here https://t.co/luaJTTVMj3 https://t.co/oT2esO5Rj7

Schnabel: Lower interest rates tend to go along with higher asset prices. But lower rates are not just the consequence of monetary policy, but of long-term structural trends, like ageing and low productivity growth, leading to high savings and low investment. #AskECB https://t.co/Aq1N1OOJfa

Schnabel: We are examining this question as part our ongoing strategy review. The scope of policy transmission may indeed change when rates are very low. Please read my recent speech for more details. #AskECB https://t.co/2E7UONnTzt https://t.co/bkI8tltgEM

Schnabel: Preserving access to public money in a digital world is a priority to central banks. A digital euro can complement market-based payment systems and leave more choice to consumers. #AskECB https://t.co/6xp3Z0wyTY

Schnabel: Asset purchases benefit all sectors. Bond yields serve as the basis for all interest rates in the economy, including for bank lending rates paid by households and firms. #AskECB https://t.co/qWMtYkK1gs

Schnabel: Our policies have avoided an even deeper economic recession and a financial crisis. They have protected jobs, which helps to mitigate the increase in inequality, which may occur due to the pandemic. We helped viable firms to bridge the deep downturn. #AskECB https://t.co/uU4pbtS3qi

Schnabel: The HICP, calculated independently by @EU_Eurostat, already includes rents. In our strategy review we are currently looking into whether and how costs for owner-occupied housing could be included. The inclusion would have to be implemented by @EU_Eurostat. #AskECB https://t.co/6wDAtaN4LH

Schnabel: In a bank-based economy like the euro area, banks are key for the transmission of our monetary policy to the real economy. Therefore, liquidity-providing measures are a standard monetary policy instrument to affect lending conditions and inflation. #AskECB https://t.co/lg460xVHPm

Schnabel: The evolution of our policy rates depends on the inflation outlook, which is currently subdued. We expect rates to remain at present or lower levels until we have seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2%. #AskECB https://t.co/ybJrZy3fbP

Schnabel: A predominant share of the increase in TARGET2 balances are a technical consequence of our asset purchases as these are often conducted through financial centres. We are therefore not concerned about the evolution of TARGET2 balances. #AskECB https://t.co/5DMN37eTwp
